postcontent: I have a very rare, and a highly desirable, special order First Model Winchester 1895 Flatside lever action sporting rifle chambered in the 30 US caliber. This rifle, serial #4232 was manufactured in 1897, has 3 special order features and comes with a Winchester Factory letter taken from the ledgers housed at the Cody Firearms Museum confirming its original configuration. The factory letter is 30 years old (from 1988) and comes in the original envelope and has the Cody Museum paperwork that came with the letter. The letter reads: Rifle, 30 caliber, Lyman receiver and front sight, No rear seat (extremely rare), and received and shipped from the warehouse on November 15, 1897. I looked at every Model 1895 featured in "The Winchester Book" written by George Madis and was not able to find another example that was sent from the factory with "No Rear Seat" in the barrel. This is the first one I have ever seen in an 1895. This is an excellent example of an early Model 1895 Flatside Rifle in Caliber 30 U.S. (30/40 Government-Krag). This is the nicest Flatside I have owned. You will only find the 1895 Flatsides in 3 calibers, the black powder cartidges 38-72 and 40-72, and then the smokeless 30/40 Krag. The former 2 calibers came standard with a 26" round or octagon barrel while the 30 U.S. came with the sleek 28" round tapered barrel with a ramp front sight. Only the first 5000 1895's had the early Flatside frame with the one piece lever (a very difficult component to manufacture) after which Winchester introduced the scalloped frame 1895 and the more economical 2-piece lever. Only 19,000 Model 1895's qualify as Pre-1898 antiques... and about 10,000 of those were muskets ordered by the U.S. Government. As for condition the receiver retains much of its original blue finish, toning some and showing lighter towards the front left side of the receiver. The original 28" round tapered barrel retains 98% of its original bluing. The original walnut stocks are in excellent condition, retaining nearly all of their original finish, with very minimal light handling marks. The wood to metal fit is tight and proud. The action is tight and smooth, mechanically perfect. The hammer retains nearly all of its original case colors. The barrel address and caliber markings are like new. The screws are very good. The special order Lyman #21 receiver sight is in excellent condition, retaining nearly all of its original blue finish. This rifle has been very well cared for over the years. title: For Sale:  SPECIAL ORDER "FLATSIDE" WINCHESTER 1895 30 US -NR HIGHER COND., LETTER Lyman #21, No Rear Seat, 1886
postcontent: I have a very rare, and a highly desirable, special order First Model Winchester 1895 Flatside lever action sporting rifle chambered in the 30 US caliber. This rifle, serial #4232 was manufactured in 1897, has 3 special order features and comes with a Winchester Factory letter taken from the ledgers housed at the Cody Firearms Museum confirming its original configuration. The factory letter is 30 years old (from 1988) and comes in the original envelope and has the Cody Museum paperwork that came with the letter. The letter reads: Rifle, 30 caliber, Lyman receiver and front sight, No rear seat (extremely rare), and received and shipped from the warehouse on November 15, 1897. I looked at every Model 1895 featured in "The Winchester Book" written by George Madis and was not able to find another example that was sent from the factory with "No Rear Seat" in the barrel. This is the first one I have ever seen in an 1895. This is an excellent example of an early Model 1895 Flatside Rifle in Caliber 30 U.S. (30/40 Government-Krag). This is the nicest Flatside I have owned. You will only find the 1895 Flatsides in 3 calibers, the black powder cartidges 38-72 and 40-72, and then the smokeless 30/40 Krag. The former 2 calibers came standard with a 26" round or octagon barrel while the 30 U.S. came with the sleek 28" round tapered barrel with a ramp front sight. Only the first 5000 1895's had the early Flatside frame with the one piece lever (a very difficult component to manufacture) after which Winchester introduced the scalloped frame 1895 and the more economical 2-piece lever. Only 19,000 Model 1895's qualify as Pre-1898 antiques... and about 10,000 of those were muskets ordered by the U.S. Government. As for condition the receiver retains much of its original blue finish, toning some and showing lighter towards the front left side of the receiver. The original 28" round tapered barrel retains 98% of its original bluing. The original walnut stocks are in excellent condition, retaining nearly all of their original finish, with very minimal light handling marks. The wood to metal fit is tight and proud. The action is tight and smooth, mechanically perfect. The hammer retains nearly all of its original case colors. The barrel address and caliber markings are like new. The screws are very good. The special order Lyman #21 receiver sight is in excellent condition, retaining nearly all of its original blue finish. This rifle has been very well cared for over the years. In all this is an excellent example of an all original, unmolested an extremely rare Model 1895 Flatside that would be a standout piece in ones collection. I guarantee you are going to love this old 1895.
